Negative tests are different... I'd write    
    public void testExceptions() {    // note no throws
        try {
            method.throwsNPE();
            fail("Should have thrown NPE");
        } catch (NullPointerException expected) {
            assertTrue("Should catch NPE", true);
        }
    }
 
to test the fact that 'method.throwsNPE' should throw NPE.
 
 
Thanks
--DP

On Jul 14, 2004, at 2:53 PM, David Plass wrote:

> What about the documentation?  If I declare more specific exceptions, 
> a la
>
>     public void testAFile() throws FileNotFoundException {
>         ...
>   }

I always declare the most specific exception, as well.  Then when 
someone (me!) comes back to see how the code under test is supposed to 
work, the exception(s) that can be raised is explicit.  That is, the 
test is an example of how the code is intended to be used.  Client code 
can always just catch Throwable, but the test documents the bare 
minimum.

> then I can document why it might fail:
>     @throws FileNotFoundException when the test file "foo" is not 
> found, but
> it should always be found. This might indicate a problem with ...

Of course, that information can also be documented in the form of a 
negative test.  It's fun to write a test that raises an expected 
exception.  The artifact of that fun is an example of what and how 
exceptions can be raised.

Mike
